dialogues.Morell:
[1]What kind is it? 
[2]And the frame? 
[3]Postmark? 
[4]No note. 
[5]I know. I'm sorry, Henrik. 
[6]I'd like to see the girl's room. 
[7]I thought this was your house. 
[8]Are her parents alive? 
[9]I want to speak to everyone here. That'll take all night so you might want someone to put some coffee on. 
[10]First thing in the morning. 
[11]We searched for days ... 
[12]Eventually, much to his dismay - and mine - I had to talk to Henrik about calling it off - 
[13]The fact that I never found a body didn't surprise me. You can't dig up an entire island. 
[14]But   I also couldn't find a motive. Was   it spontaneous? Was it planned? Did   she know something someone wished she   didn't? Was it about business? 
[15]And very bright. Henrik told me he could easily imagine her running the business someday, which would mean someone else wouldn't. 
[16]She told them she wasn't feeling well. She left early. But they also said she kept secrets from them, too. The main thing I learned talking to them for hours is that teenage girls are complicated. 
[17]So you know. Did you bring the last gift Henrik received? 
[18]I can tell you what their report will say now: It's a flower common to Europe. All of them are. No prints. No DNA. 
[19]She received this from Henrik the Christmas before. I studied it more times than I can say. I know every page of it. 
[20]As was I. 
[21]They're local Hedestad phone numbers. The first belonged to a woman named Margot, whose mother was Magda, who claimed she didn't know Harriet. The fourth, R.L., belonged to Rosemarie Larsson, an elderly woman who died a few years before. The other three were unconnected in any way that I could find. 
[22]I can't forget it. It's my Rebecka Case. 
[23]Every policeman has at least one unsolved case. Back then it was old Torstensson. Year after year he kept returning to one - taking out the files - uselessly studying them. As young men, we had to laugh. 
[24]No, that's not why I mention it. The Rebecka Case is something that happened before Harriet was born. I'm talking about the soul of a policeman. Poor Torstensson could never solve it, and could never let it go.
dialogues.Frode:
[1]You called her, I thought.     You spoke to her. 
[2]I don't understand. 
[3]But you told her I wanted to meet her. 
[4]But you like her. 
[5]But. 
[6]In what way. 
[7]How do you do? 
[8]No. It seems quite thorough. There's a wealth of data here. But I'm also interested to know what's not in it. 
[9]Your opinion of him isn't. 
[10]So you don't have one? 
[11]He's - excuse me? 
[12]There's less in his asset column after his conviction today. 
[13]Are you saying he was set up? 
[14]You're quite right he made a fool of himself professionally. How big of a fool did he make of himself financially? 
[15]Your report is light in another area. His personal life. Anything you chose not to include? 
[16]I'm not sure if that means yes or no. 
[17]Not in this case. I have to know if there's anything about him I might find unsavory - even if she doesn't. 
[18]You were right not to include that. 
[19]Anything else? 
[20]Please think before you say no. 
[21]I don't want to be surprised by something later. 
[22]So. Nothing else. In the personal department. You're sure. 
[23]Mr. Blomkvist? 
[24]Forgive me for intruding on your Christmas. My name is Dirch Frode. I'm an attorney. I represent Henrik Vanger. Perhaps you've heard of - 
[25]He'd like to speak to you about a private matter. 
[26]I'm sorry. I'm about to sit down to Christmas dinner myself. 
[27]You're referring to your recent legal trouble. That has provided Mr. Vanger with some entertainment. 
[28]He doesn't care for Wennerstrom either. 
[29]He'd like to meet in person if that's okay. Up north. Hedestad. 
[30]He's much too old to make a trip to Stockholm, Mr. Blomkvist. Please. If you'd be so kind as to consider. 
[31]Hedestad is lovely in winter.      Like a Christmas card. 
[32]First time in Hedestad? 
[33]It's lovely in the spring. 
[34]This is unseasonable. 
[35]Unless we get snowed in ... I'm joking. You'll be home tonight, if that's what you wish.

dialogues.Anita:
[1]It's fine.    Please.     Have a seat. 
[2]Mikael.   How do you do. 
[3]You're looking for investment counseling, Mikael? 
[4]Excuse me? 
[5]How is Henrik? 
[6]I haven't seen him in over 30 years. Or my sister. Or anyone else in my family. 
[7]I wouldn't know where to start, if that was a question.  
[8]Harriet. Everything I knew about that I told to - whatever his name was - that policeman - when it happened. 
[9]My recollections then were a lot better than they are now.  
[10]She was messed up. Like all us Vanger kids. Crazy mother. Drunken father. At least hers wasn't a Nazi like mine.  
[11]Mine? 
[12]I never saw it myself, but you could tell something was going on. One day she'd be withdrawn. The next she'd be putting on makeup and wearing the tightest sweater she had to school. The next she'd be studying a Bible like a nun - no Vanger was ever religious - can you imagine? Obviously, she was very unhappy. 
[13]There was no specifically. It was everything. It was being part of that family. Henrik's the only decent person in it. 
[14]Everyone knows what. 
[15]All I know is I always felt sorry for her. Even more than for myself. I got out of there when I was 18 and never went back. She would have done the same but didn't make it to 18.
